page.title: 03Hatfield Broad Oak Houses
page.content: Much of the charm of the village lies in the pleasing variety of styles of architecture. The oldest cottages are timber-framed, some of them incorporating a four hundred year old structure behind a more recent facade. The exterior aspects include attractive specimens of pargetting or ornamental plasterwork and plain Essex boarding. Some of the old cottages are still thatched, although in many cases the roofs are now slate or tile. Nineteenth century buildings include 'Great Chalks' (the former vicarage) and 'Brick House', both in the High Street. Barrington Hall, the former manor house, was begun in 1735 but was not completed until 1863. The more recent houses include bungalows, 'council houses' (built by the local authority) and several areas developed by local builders.
